asthma-action-plan-info-view-info: For the most up to date information about Asthma Action Plans, please refer to this library article.
asthma-action-plan-info-view-subtitle: Stay in control of your asthma with a personalized Asthma Action Plan (AAP) from your provider.  An AAP includes a plan for each of three key zones: Green/Go, Yellow/Caution, Red/Danger.
asthma-action-plan-manager-instructions: Save a photo of your asthma action plan for easy reference.
asthma-action-plan-manager-instructions-: Save a photo of {name}'s asthma action plan for easy reference.

asthma-heart-and-lungs-view-dbol-alert-m: Your daytime blood oxygen is below your normal level.
asthma-heart-and-lungs-view-dhr-alert-me: Your daytime resting heart rate is above your normal level.
asthma-heart-and-lungs-view-nbol-alert-m: Your nighttime blood oxygen is below your normal level.
asthma-heart-and-lungs-view-nhr-alert-me: Your nighttime resting heart rate is above your normal level.
asthma-heart-and-lungs-view-rr-alert-mes: Your respiratory rate is above your normal level.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-ai: Explore the mechanics of asthma and how it leads to the classic asthma symptoms.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-as: Dive into a wealth of questions answered by an allergist ranging from the impact of food allergies on asthma to managing pet allergies and the effects of long COVID.
Stay in control of your asthma with a personalized Asthma Action Plan (AAP) from your provider.  An AAP includes a plan for each of three key zones: Green/Go, Yellow/Caution, Red/Danger.
Understand that poor air quality can trigger asthma. Learn how to navigate high AQI days and what AQI levels mean.
Animals/Pets can be a trigger for asthma. Learn about how to diagnose an animal/pet allergy and steps to reduce the impact.
Dust is a common asthma trigger, but the reason it is a trigger may surprise you!
What is heartburn and what does it have to do with asthma?
Mold needs moisture to grow, so is typically found in damp or wet places. Learn how to prevent mold in your house.
Respiratory infections are common asthma triggers. How to prevent them and what to do when they occur.
Navigate pollen season with ease: Identify your specific pollen triggers, understand their seasonal patterns, and learn how to minimize exposure.
Wildfires and tobacco smoke can trigger asthma. Learn about steps you can take to reduce your exposure.
Common weather triggers are cold air, hot and humid air, and rain/thunderstorms. Explore why these can trigger asthma.
Recognize the early signs of an asthma attack and learn to act swiftly with your action plan to prevent escalation.
Having a doctor/provider is an essential part of asthma management. Learn about the different types of doctors that are trained to manage asthma.
Learn how to identify common and uncommon side effects, and the simple steps you can take to avoid the common side effect - thrush (fungal infection in your mouth).
Learn about asthma in this quick overview.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-ca: Unravel the differences between quick-relief, controller, and combination medications and understand their roles in asthma management.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-di: Identifying your asthma triggers is key to being able to manage your asthma. Learn about common triggers and how to track them.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-ho: Controller medications can take days to weeks to reach full impact. Track your symptoms daily to see if there is an improvement and if there isn't, talk to your provider.
Stay symptom-free by adhering to your treatment plan, understanding triggers, and early recognition of changes in control.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-in: Dry Powder inhaler (DPI) technique tips. Without the right technique, you may be only getting part of the dose.
Metered dose inhaler (MDI) technique tips. Without the right technique, you may be only getting part of the dose.
Soft Mist Inhaler (SMI) technique tips. Without the right technique, you may be only getting part of the dose.
Explore asthma treatment devices - including 3 different inhalers and a nebulizer.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-is: 4 questions to assess if your asthma is under control. If you're experiencing symptoms more than 2 times a week or if you are waking up at night from asthma symptoms - your asthma is not under control.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-li: Learn from the success stories of renowned athletes like David Beckham and Rashad Jennings, who've managed their asthma to excel in sports.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-me: For when cost is a barrier to medications, learn about free or low-cost medications. Taking medications as prescribed is important to maintaining asthma control.
Stay on top of your asthma medication with easy refill strategies.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-na: Recognize severe symptoms like intense coughing and breathlessness early, and activate your tailored asthma action plan including immediate medications.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-pr: Arm yourself with a summary of your asthma logs to facilitate an informed discussion by tracking regularly. Write down questions that you have and bring your medications.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-st: Discover what smells may trigger your asthma and things to think about while cleaning.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-su: Uncover unexpected asthma triggers lurking in your daily life, from NSAIDs (like ibuprofen) to your glass of wine. Knowing what to look for, may help you identify these surprise triggers.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-ta: When your asthma feels unmanageable, it's time to reassess your approach. Steps to take when your asthma is not under control.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-tr: Unlock a deeper understanding of your asthma through regular symptom tracking, which will allow you to identify patterns and triggers. Each entry can be a step toward a more informed, healthier life with asthma.
Discover simple yet effective strategies to remember your daily doses, from smart storage tips to leveraging app reminders.
asthma-library-category-view-subtitle-wh: Learn about asthma control through a simple analogy: keeping your lungs 'wet' to prevent 'fires' (attacks) from asthma triggers.
Master your asthma management: Rescue inhaler works quickly to relieve symptoms while a controller is preventative and works by reducing inflammation, typically by being taken daily.
Discover the crucial role of controller medications in maintaining asthma under control.
Understand the critical role of controller medications and why they're a cornerstone of your personalized management plan.
asthma-library-category-view-title-how-d: How do I know if my asthma medications are working?
asthma-library-category-view-title-how-t: How to keep your asthma under control
asthma-library-category-view-title-navig: Navigating the Danger Zone: Preparedness for Asthma Flare-Ups
asthma-library-category-view-title-why-s: Why should I take my controller?
asthma-log-entry-info-view-p1: Logging and editing are only allowed for today and yesterday. Further back than that, it is difficult to accurately remember how you are feeling. Try to take time at a routine time each day to complete your daily entry and if something changes after that (new symptoms or triggers), you can always go back in and edit.
asthma-log-entry-info-view-p2: Without regular logging, it is easy to overlook mild symptoms. Regular logging allows for a moment of reflection on how you've been feeling and ensures you have a detailed history to discuss with your healthcare provider. Research has revealed that individuals who kept a symptom diary recalled their symptoms with double the frequency and significantly greater detail than those who didn't. This practice not only aids in communication with doctors but can also play a crucial role in managing your asthma more effectively.
